bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Marietta Pritchard is a writer, editor and activist in Massachusetts. She was born in Budapest, Hungary to Eva Furth Perl and George Perl. The family immigrated to the U.S. in 1939 and settled in Scarsdale, New York. Pritchard graduated from Scarsdale High School in 1954, and received her B.A. from Radcliffe College in 1958; she went on to earn a M.Ed. from the University of Massachusetts in 1973. She has been married to Amherst College professor William Pritchard since 1957; the couple has three sons. From 1964 to 1976, Pritchard taught in public and private schools. From 1970 to 1977 she was a member of Amherst Town Meeting, and she has volunteered in ESL and GED programs and at the Hospice of the Fisher Home in Amherst. From 1977 to 1989, Pritchard was features editor at the Daily Hampshire Gazette in Northampton, MA; from 1989 to 1990, she was senior editor of New England Magazine; and since 1989 she has worked as a freelance writer and editor for publications, organizations and individuals.
The Amherst Women's Liberation (AWL) support group, the subject of her unpublished book, formed in 1969. By 1970 it had grown to one hundred members, meeting weekly in support groups and a large monthly forum in a church. Study groups on abortion and birth control, archves, continuing education, and welfare were formed. In December 1970, AWL opened the Valley Women's Center (VWC) with action groups, a newsletter, speaker's bureau, staff group, free personal counseling, and welfare advocacy and counseling.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Marietta Pritchard papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00651, Smith College, Northampton, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These papers contain materials pertaining to Pritchard's unpublished book about the Amherst Women's Liberation support group, which started in 1969. Included is the complete typescript, entitled "Life Support: A Women's Group Four Decades Later"; questionnaires; interviews with former members (audio recordings and transcripts); correspondence; and notes. The collection also includes other writings by Pritchard and subject files on women's issues. Photographs of Pritchard (electronic) were added in Dec. 2010.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, Marietta Pritchard has assigned the copyright in her works to Smith College; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Pritchard, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.
